Topic.Title: Another meandering day.

And, by the way, will do just fine regardless of deflation or inflation because it has maintained a flexible cost structure with its contract manufacturing network on the deflation side and obviously will do better in nominal terms on the inflation side...

Topic.Title: Amazon Ponzi article on Seeking Alpha...

Message.Msg: techstrategy, That's a great article. Probably not exactly the same aggressive accounting but CRM is another company richly rewarding insiders while not generating any GAAP earnings as the stock goes through the roof, but all in due time before that bubble pops. Sorry, I digress, in what universe does a company get away with giving out as little detail as possible on their conference calls while sell side analysts seem like they are privileged to be able to ask a question on the conference call to the great and Wonderful Oz's team. Make no mistake about it this is a real company and a great service company but let it be evaluated on a real basis like most other companies are. The premium is way too high, like a ball of string that can reach the moon. Doesn't that sound like one of Amazon's analogies that they use in describing their results. For now and until further notice it will trade at sky high levels, but when the first few rats (sell side analysts) run for the exits, the last bigger fool will be left holding the bag. That could be $100 north of here or not so to Nas's credit I will say trade accordingly, although I don't anticipate going long. It's most likely inevitable, that the folks competing in this space(s) either have to be valued higher or more likely the reversion to the mean, albeit still with a premium, will have to occur here, especially if sales are slowing. Good luck.

Topic.Title: Amazon Ponzi article on Seeking Alpha...

Message.Msg: Hapi: For those of us that understand what is really happening in the global economy and the true nature of the repricing of assets that is underway but will accelerate massively, AMZN is actually going to see its relative competitiveness degrade massively. And I'm not talking about sales tax collection. The fundamental economic tradeoff embedded within the business model has been moving against Amazon and will continue to move against Amazon. It will have to spend a ton just to limit the damage.

Topic.Title: Amazon Ponzi article on Seeking Alpha...

Message.Msg: Of course, he would have done well to also point out that gross shipping cost as a % of net sales is also increasing... Doesn't quite fit the analyst story... Some notes from the 10K: (2) Includes a portion of amounts earned from Amazon Prime memberships. (3) Shipping revenue for the three months and nine months ended September 30, 2012, includes amounts earned from Fulfillment by Amazon programs related to shipping services. Kind of materially affects the shipping cost reduction story...

Topic.Title: So, do you think Yahoo is censoring people (Sybil, Techstrategy, others) or is it a 3rd party?

Message.Msg: Geeg, it was no accident earlier. My connection was blocked across all of my devices. It wouldn't even let me access the message boards. This is factual and again, I took screenshots on multiple devices. Either Yahoo is censoring (and I intend to make sure they affirm the intent to do so), or some 3rd party is getting in pretty deep.

Topic.Title: So, do you think Yahoo is censoring people (Sybil, Techstrategy, others) or is it a 3rd party?

Message.Msg: I should be clear that ONLY the Yahoo message boards were blocked. That was no accident. And, it was right after I pointed out that the gross shipping cost growing as a percent of sales (and the increased shipping revenue offset not only from FBA but Prime transfers) that it happened. I don't know how long it will take to get an answer from Yahoo as to whether it is doing it or someone else, but either way I intend to understand who is actively blocking critical perspectives on this board...

Message.Title: Hapi: the periods of the Fe's easy money is when the games happen: we are right in the middle of outright printing of money every month
Message.Msg: when that is happening, you can sell the story withotu earnings. If earnings trumped the money printing of Bernanke wichi is now over $3.1 trillion , AMZN wouldn't trade at 275/shr with none of them When Bernanke has a $800 billion balance sheet in 2008-9 , AMZN was expensive at about 40-50 times earnings but that was at a stock base of about 50-100. So you see how important the Bernanke printing is to the analyst /media story. It's not coincidence, it's correlated. And Bernanke shows no signs of letting up on the $85 billion a month of bond buying. In turn,, that money for bonds is circulated to the banks to sell these stories and take everything higher. Money printed has to go somewhere: earnings backed or not.

Message.Msg: What it's also doing is helping Bezos become the richest person in the world on the back of Bernanke's printing and he doesn't even have to show earnings to get there. Not bad to be Bezos having such Fed backiing now is it?

Topic.Title: Ponzi Scheme

Message.Msg: Although he did miss that gross shipping cost are growing as a percent of sales... Recognition of shipping revenue from FBA and allocated revenue from Prime in 2012 makes the YOY reduction in net shipping misleading. Look at the 10-K. Nor did he catch that days payable has gone from 72 (2010) to 74 (2011) to 76 since (2012)...

Topic.Title: Ponzi Scheme

Message.Msg: Someone might look into the cash position as well... almost half sits overseas, primarily in GBP, EUR, and JPY. I hope AMZN has hedged USD...

Topic.Title: Ponzi Scheme

Message.Msg: For net shipping cost, compare to 2010. Even with the increased revenue transfers in 2012, it is higher than 2010, despite the increased investment in distribution facilities. Just another inconvenient fact that invalidates the story.... This is a lot closer to a ponzi than people realize...

Topic.Title: Ponzi Scheme

Message.Msg: Hi techstrategy. What an upside down market, huh? Looks like baby boomers had a good year and are throwing their tax refunds into retirement accounts and then buying equity funds. We all know how well momentum investing works. Come April 15, this bubble will bust, if not sooner. In the mean time, I am just sitting in cash and watching bear oriented mutual funds. Cuo.
